title: CTRL0000916064 - Transcribed Interview of Shealah D. Craighead, (June 29, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:10 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
So this is a resumed transcribed interview of Ms. Shealah Craighead conducted by
the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States
And, Ms. Craighead, we have met before, but if you could please introduce
yourself again just for the record, I'd appreciate it.
I had the role of the director of the White House
photo department and the official chief photographer to President Donald Trump during
And, counsel, if you don't mind introducing yourself just for the record as well.
Adam Kaufmann from Lewis Baach Kaufmann Middlemiss, representing
And Jon Gryskiewicz, also from Lewis Baach, also for Ms.
- h a n k you both.
So just like last time, it's the same people on our side.
Just as a reminder, the official record is done via a court reporter, stenographer.
And so as they take it down, it's just helpful if you let me finish my question before
answering and I'll let you finish your answer before asking the next question.
And nonverbal responses, like shaking your head, can't really be taken down.
if we ask you to repeat an answer, it's only for the benefit of the transcript.
And then, of course, just like I reminded before, not specific to you,
Ms. Craighead, but we remind all our witnesses that it is unlawful to deliberately provide
So, otherwise, everything remains the same.
And do you have any questions?
Then let's get right into it.
So I want to talk to you a little bit about January 7th, the day after the attack
some remarks and perhaps were developing remarks as well.
And I understand that you were present while the President filmed
Can you tell us what you
I remember that day was -- the taping in particular was on the
schedule, but it was scheduled for a time period that would have been within an hour
from that day, so I'm speaking based on memory.
And I should say I don't have the schedule in front of me or the notes
And so from that, we had about an hour for the taping, which would have been in
the Diplomatic Receiving Room, in the Dip Room as it's called.
schedule, if anything, on the official schedule.
And then I can't recall what we had for the rest of the day on the
But what was interesting about that taping in particular that I observed was it took
twice as long as it was scheduled for.
I -- on the -- if you were to look at the time stamp
on my camera, you'll see -- you'll follow through the taping through -- from start to finish.
And in between the finish of the taping, we paused to do the event, and I believe that we
ran late to the event as well.
So it sounds like the President had on his schedule time to film his remarks that he
I think we ran about 20 minutes late or so to the event.
And we'll just kind of walk through it.
ultimately delivered to the country on January the 7th.
I actually was trying to remember where it was at, what room that it was
And it was originally scheduled to be about an our hour in the
Do you remember the event that came after it that you had to go
held in, if it was held in the West Wing or on the State Floor.
Who else was in the room while you were doing the taping for the Presidential
Based on memory, it would have been the teleprompter person.
would have been the WHCA, the White House communication office, doing the taping.
It could have been members of the communication team.
And it would have been, of course, a Secret Service agent potentially, or that
person might have been -- or people might have been on the outside of the Dip Room.
The video team, the audiovisual team that you saw in the Rose Garden the day
1was going to say, the legal team.
It was the legal -- there was members of the -- multiple members of the legal
There was quite a few people in there.
team, and the -- I believe Jared and lvanka, Dan Scavino, and perhaps one of his members
It could have been Nick Luna or one of the members of the
And when you say the legal team, do you remember who from the
Based off memory, it would have been likely -- oh, and a speechwriter.
not entirely sure which speechwriter would have been in there.
Based off of memory, it would have been Scott Gast or Pat Cipollone.
could have been one or two other folks.
Do you remember Eric Herschmann being there?
Eric could have been there, yes.
Throughout the time it was sort of revolving or evolving through.
be -- I wouldn't be surprised if he was there.
He was in the Oval Office area a lot in the
So it wouldn't be surprising for him to be in the room.
Do you remember the Chief of Staff, Mark Meadows, being there?
It just didn't -- taping typically didn't -- to have a chief of staff there -- I don't
It doesn't make sense, I guess, because he was fully
So it didn't really make sense to have the Chief of Staff there.
And based, I assume, on your experience
just working in the West Wing and events that he would go to and certain events he
Also based on his schedule or needs, so --
Could we have just -- could I have a brief moment just to speak
to Ms. Craighead just for a moment?
How do we do that in this format?
- h a t I will do is I will go on mute and stop our video.
suggest both of you do the same and then maybe have a phone call.
And we'll go off the record.
Then let's go back on the record.
We're resuming the transcribed interview of Ms. Shealah Craighead.
And I think where we left off you were describing what you remembered
about people who were in the room when the President filmed his remarks on January
So I guess at this point can you walk us through what you remember when you got
to the room, the Diplomatic Room, for the President's taping of the remarks on the 7th?
I remember the room being very crowded and sort of revolving or
evolving people coming in and out.
and the teleprompter team off to the video camera's right side.
I remember the taping setup with the video team
And, let's see, you had the setup of the podium against the fireplace.
was a table, like a small table, with beverages or whatever was needed on the
right -- water, you know -- on the right side of that.
And before the President came in, were you there?
I stayed with him from the Oval to the Diplomatic Room.
And when you walked in with the President, were there any discussions
going on or any comments about what the President would do or say?
And that -- so that's the general
I don't recall specifically how that was unfolding.
He would do a run-through of the remarks before taping, and there was a lot of
input in the room from multiple people.
I couldn't be specific, though, on conversations.
Before you got to the Diplomatic Room, do you remember any
he wanted to deliver on the 7th?
Did the President say anything about the remarks that
And then when you get in there, tell us what you do recall about the
tapings or the run-through, I guess, initially and what the President wanted to say or do.
The taping -- so in my observation, his demeanor was hesitant to say
conversations with he and members in the Dip Room about the words or what he was
comfortable saying or wasn't comfortable saying.
There were multiple changes to the context in the words, multiple
And he seemed to be very agitated about the taping.
it was lots of stops and starts, lots of -- lots of starts and stops.
Asking for something to drink, asking for something -- another
Just sort of -- lots of repeated stops and starts.
You mentioned that he was hesitant to say certain words.
remember which words or the types of words or phrases the President was hesitant to
Were there any themes that you remember him not wanting to deliver?
My understanding was that he wanted to -- my observation was that he
wanted to -- the team, I believe, was Pat and lvanka encouraging his conversation
in specific -- in -- the speech in a specific direction, and he was not comfortable with that.
But that was the general -- there was a
lot -- there seemed to be -- there were lots of back and forth on the speech and changes
made to it in real time while he was taping.
Do you remember him having a paper copy of the speech that he was
I'll represent to you that some of the documents that we've
obtained as part of the investigation show that the President crossed out certain
language -- and I'm paraphrasing here -- but language about prosecuting certain rioters to
the fullest extent of the law.
Do you remember anything about that?
In the taping he was reading from a teleprompter, so he didn't have
paper in front of him, if I recall properly.
specifically from the teleprompter across the room.
you elaborate on that at all?
Do you remember him saying or doing anything that would
Based on previous tapings he has done, he's a spot-on -- he's really
direct and spot-on with his taping.
And you said he was agitated and there were a lot of stops and starts.
But that would -- he wouldn't -- he was reading
He's typically very one or two takes, call it a day.
So it alerted me that -- the difference on this taping was notable to me because of
the time it took and the multiple stops and starts and the frustration he seemed to be
showing if the -- through -- by stopping and starting multiple times and changing words.
And we may have covered this already, but do you recall any specific
remarks or themes that Pat Cipollone, lvanka, or anybody else in the room were
Do you remember -- oh, go ahead.
Do you remember any suggestions that the President just -- he had to do this
I didn't mean to cut you off.
or he needed to be stronger in his words?
I can give you my observation.
But I can't give you the exact phrases.
The observation of lvanka and Pat were to offer support in the -- of the transition.
And that was not -- that had not been conveyed before.
And when you say offer support in the transition, are you talking
about the transition to the new administration, the Biden administration?
Do you remember the issue of the President wanting to say anything about
pardons or pardoning anybody who had been associated with the attack coming up?
Now, you mentioned earlier that originally the taping of the remarks on the
7th had been scheduled for an hour.
So is it the case that they were not completed
And you went off to the other event, it sounds like, as an interlude and then
Do you remember about how long it took once you got back for the President to
finish taping the remarks on the 7th?
I believe the entire -- I believe it took within an hour.
of the taping that was scheduled was scheduled for about an hour, I believe.
second part of that taping took within an hour.
It didn't go much further than that
And was it your impression that the President was still reluctant or, in your
words, agitated in that second session, the second hour of the taping?
The second taping was more fluid and more confident in his, in my
I mean, did he talk to anybody in
between the taping sessions or did he talk to somebody once he got back for the second
round of taping that you recall?
Is there anything you noticed that changed between the sessions
There were changes made to the speech in between that on the
And so when he came back, he was ready to -- the
teleprompter was ready for him to jump into the speech again.
Do you know if those were changes that he had made or suggested to the
Bear with us just one moment.
Ms. Craighead, specific to the first go-around, that first hour when the
President was agitated and hesitant, some of the language we've seen in the initial draft
of the speech that was changed included words to the effect of the President saying that
the people who attacked the Capitol did not represent him and did not represent his
Do you remember that being one of the things that he was hung up on as he was
trying to deliver those remarks in the first hour; in other words, disassociating the people
who attacked from himself and his supporters?
I don't recall specifically on that.
And understanding specifics, it's important to be -- I mean, if you don't
what you recall generally about what it was that he was pushing back against saying, just
But, I mean, can you just tell us in your own words
What was the thrust of it that he had a problem with?
Generally it was -- he was still not -- the
election was still -- let me start over, please.
The atmosphere and the mood, in my observation, based on what I saw, was that
he was still very much against the transition of the next President and administration
His agitation to me, in my observation, was that he wasn't able to speak the
So I understood that to be his general -- what was hard for him to follow
It was very hard for him to get the words out in that speech.
So I am not aware of what happened in between the first taping and the second
taping, but there was change, and he was able to fluently say the words in confident and
move forward in that taping pretty smoothly.
The first half was very choppy, very
And understanding he was agitated during that first hour, what was the
demeanor and posture that lvanka and Mr. Cipollone were taking toward the President
and how they were addressing him?
Were they -- how would you describe that?
Very supportive, kind, encouraging of speaking positively to the Nation, of
speaking supportively into the transition, of speaking -- of saying in the speech the
That was the general tone and atmosphere in that
Understand the words that they wanted conveyed and the theme, but in
terms of their communications with the President about getting him to say this, what was
the -- what was their emotional state?
using elevated voices to try to get him to say the words?
elevated voices or demands or, you know, strong words would not be in their character
say -- to convey to America to say the words that needed to be said, from their
They were very supportive in their tone and encouragement to
But the mood in the room, the observation that I saw was of support to get
through the speech, from the law team, the counsels, and lvanka as well.
Do you remember any conversations about the President wanting to blame
outside groups, other than his supporters, for the attack on the Capitol, like antifa or
What about other than during that filming session?
Is there anything else that you can remember about that or anything
else on the topics we've covered today that you would like to share?
again and for reconvening today, Ms. Craighead.
At this point, unless there's anything you or your counsel have to put on the
record, I'll give you an opportunity to do so.
Looks like you're shaking your head.
I was just going to say my concern is that I don't remember
specifics, but I can tell you the mood.
And my hesitation in that is speculating, and I
The mood in the room was -- in the whole environment -- was very tense.
mood in the whole West Wing was very tense.
And it was -- and your question about the conversations about blaming other
people, antifa, that wasn't -- there aren't specifics, because it seemed to be -- and I'm
saying this off the record because it seemed to be very -- he just wasn't accepting of, as
we know, he just wasn't accepting of the elections.
And he certainly wasn't accepting of the transition.
that we had to do with transitioning to the new administration, it was almost that you
just didn't talk about it because you would be -- it would seem that you were against the
I was mentioning to Adam and Jon that I gave a tour to the incoming director of
the photo department, with management's permission and conversation as protocol
wasn't the attitude of the environment, so to speak.
But I didn't mention to anybody else that I was doing that because it just
There was a hard divide between the President and the Vice President's team, as
you can imagine, after that day.
But the mood was that you just sort of let it -- you
Because you didn't -- the amount of trust in that environment was completely
in a way that was professionally handled to -- and not taking anything personally or
emotionally, because it just -- the energy and the environment was just really highly
So you didn't know who to trust or who not to trust.
So you just -- you just didn't know what it -- if you were to say, "I'm proceeding
with the transition," how that would be proceeded -- how that would be received by
anybody in that immediate circle, as maybe you're a traitor, maybe you're not; maybe
you're not on board with our administration, maybe you are.
You know, you just didn't know, so you just sort of flew under the radar to get out,
to finish up the last 2 weeks and just depart.
So the environment was a very tricky environment to navigate.
know -- I don't -- I didn't know how to convey that to you without -- because I don't have
hard facts, and I just didn't want to speculate that on record.
I do recall lvanka being very supportive of her dad saying the right words for
America, the supportive words that she -- that needed to happen, the transition, peaceful
transition, you know, in that speech.
It was a really, really toxic and tricky environment to navigate.
I believe Pat Cipollone as well was also in that environment, and Eric Herschmann.
But I couldn't --1 can't -- without seeing the photos, I can't replay -- I can't replay exactly
who was in that room, and it was evolving and revolving throughout the entire time.
His agitation of stopping and starting the conversation was
based on asking for Diet Cokes several times, or stopping to take a sip and then starting
again, immediately stopping and taking another sip and then starting again, reading some
of the scroll, and then asking for a new Coca-Cola, or needing a towel to wipe his head or
It was just there is anything -- you know, as you procrastinate, you're finding
anything to do not to do what you have to do.
That's what it seemed like in my
Anything that he could procrastinate with before getting the words out he
So that's what I can give you as my observation.
People were in and out of the room.
I'd have to see the photos.
I don't recall the Chief of Staff being in there.
But they were very much by his
And, like I said, because it just
didn't seem like he would -- that would be a place where he goes to -- that didn't seem
like where he would be, because there was -- he was -- the President was overly staffed.
But perhaps he came in and out.
Again, I can't recall without seeing the photos.
So -- and then WCHA, the White House communication office, they, I believe,
were also taping, as well as the video team.
So, you know, all of that would be in the National Archives, as well, on video that
you could see, as well as the still images.
So, yeah, let's go on the record.
This is resuming the transcribed interview of Ms. Shealah Craighead.
And for the record, after we went off there was a brief conversation that we had
with Ms. Craighead, and she recounted certain events from January the 7th as well as in
the general post-election and post-January 6th period.
And so, Ms. Craighead, we'd ask your permission to include that which was
recorded by the Webex platform into the official record of today's proceedings.
And then we'll work with the official reporter and ask that the official reporters
include that period and that conversation, your comments into the record.
And with that, I think we can go off the record.
[Whereupon, at 10:55 a.m., the interview was concluded.]
I have read the foregoing _ _ pages, which contain the correct transcript of the
answers made by me to the questions therein recorded.
